title: Monday, 10th December 2018
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Morning.

Blank canvas Greetings from Madrid
chopper bear morning
Soundbuy Morning
BE11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's whatever.

chopper bear any grey on silence therapeutics settlement ? sorry for small cap so early on
BE11:03am

Been chasing about on stuff this morning, meaning I've been able to do neither of my actual jobs, so don't expect much competence today.

Manxish Morning everyone
MassimoJ morning
Soundbuy Silence Therapeutics.........they certainly came off worse in that scrap........
Soundbuy ..............though shocking liquidity.......
11:04 am
BE11:05am

Meaning we might as well just go straight into the smalls.

npf1 BASF please
Soundbuy .............price-wise rather that result-wise i may add
Silence Therapeutics PLC (SLN:LSE): Last: 71.46, down 14.54 (-16.91%), High: 84.20, Low: 71.46, Volume: 104.26k
BE11:06am

So -- settled litigation with Alnylam.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Involving tiered royalty on annual net EU sales on patisiran of 0.33-1% through 2023.

GBKrona Hola
BE11:07am

Patisiran being the treatment for polyneuropathy in people with hereditary transthyretin-mediated amyloidosis. I'm so glad to be talking about this first thing on a Monday morning.

BE11:08am

The upshot is that it's much, much worse a paydown than expected.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:08am

We recognise that new management has never oversold the value of litigation (and we risk adjusted in our SOTP model) but that this outcome – whilst good news in putting ongoing risk and litigation cost behind us – is different to previous management’s communication of potential and our assumptions in the model (including £10m milestone and estimated royalties of 2-5%).

BE11:08am

This is validation of Silence’s expertise in the RNAi chemistry. New management is much more focused on pipeline and expects to build this out in the near future and is well capitalised for this (PHe 2018E of c£37m cash prior to adjusting for the milestones/todays news).

tonyb Just Group please
ElonTheMask Altran Technologies SA?
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Further terms of the agreement include the grant from Silence to Alnylam of a non-exclusive, global irrevocable, license to all relevant patents and for all current and future Alnylam products (whether commercialised by Alnylam, a collaborator or a licensee). Under this agreement, all ongoing court proceedings will now be dismissed. We will review with new management and temporarily move to U/R – we will update our model in due course, in order to assess new management’s perspective on timelines and indications now that litigation is out of the way.

BE11:09am

Future news flow – with the sensitivities of litigation now behind us, the company will now be able to focus on applying its RNAi expertise to the pipeline. In the near- to medium-future, we believe the company is likely to be able to update on:
• The outcome of sub-licensed IP to Quark (partnered with Novartis) for QPI1002 (currently Phase 3), where SLN are eligible for c1-4% royalties or c15%
of clinical/commercial milestone payments.
• Developments in SLN’s pipeline for new and existing assets. The lead candidate SLN124 for beta-thalassaemia, with CTA planned for H1 2019).

BE11:10am

Which was the company linked with Silence back in October?

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Amicus Therapeutics, wasn't it?

Soundbuy Amicus
RAVER morning
BE11:13am

Anyway, Peel Hunt's the only broker to publish here and I have no view whatsoever. So, move on.

BE11:13am

(@ElonTheMask: what about it?)

11:13 am
undefined
jaws BE was it it Cidara Therapeutics, for SLN ?
FATDAZ Morning cant see Bryce's comments is anyone else having that issue ?
FATDAZ sorted now
BE11:14am

(@Jaws: not that I remember.)

Finlay Peel hunt on housebuilders? (it was a toss up between dinner party live and more Brexit)
BE11:15am

Just Group requested. Sure, why not. Let's go from hereditary transthyretin-mediated amyloidosis to transitional relief on regulatory capital requirements for equity release mortgages.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

It's wall-to-wall clickbait this morning. The hit rate will surely be in the dozens.

Just Group PLC (JUST:LSE): Last: 100.00, up 17.9 (+21.80%), High: 103.90, Low: 95.15, Volume: 8.80m
Flaneur @Finlay - some of us think they're the same thing....)
BE11:16am

So, the PRA's done nothing.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

The stuff proposed in the July consultation paper has been scrapped and we're back to .... well, not quite square one, but square two at most.

BE11:17am

Barclays to summarise:

BE11:17am

The PRA has announced this morning the final policy statement (31/18) on the capital treatment of equity release mortgages. The final outcome is considerably less onerous than originally set out in the 3rd July Consultation Paper. The PRA has set the deferment rate of 1% (in line with our base case and versus Just’s current assumptions of -0.5%), volatility adjustment of 13% (towards the bottom end of the anticipated 13% to 16% range and versus Just’s current assumption of 12%), and a full transitional on business written pre Solvency 2 to 2031 (in line with the normal transitional). This outcome is better than our base case assumptions of 1% deferment rate and a 6 year transitional, and indeed better than our upside case assumption of a nine year transitional. We would note that Just and the industry has already adjusted (increased) annuity pricing for a 1% deferment rate on new business.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

In our view, this is a very favorable outcome for Just, which gives the company the flexibility to continue as a going concern in what we view as one of the most attractive insurance markets in Europe, as we discussed in our recent note “Directs are the key to £180bn market”. Just operates in three growth markets (bulk annuities, individual annuities and equity release mortgages), and its problem was not its new business franchise, but whether it had the capital to take advantage of the opportunities. The company has a range of capital options (restricted debt capacity, reinsurance capacity, lower dividends etc) which it can use to raise the capital required to take advantage of the attractive markets.

Finlay @Flaneur - true, I'm trying to pretend that at least part of my life isn't just waiting for the latest Brexit incompetence.
BE11:18am

We estimate the impact of the implementation of the Final Policy Statement will be c£65m or 3 points impact on Solvency in 2019, and an additional £40m or 2 point drag for the following 12 years as the transitional is amortized. We estimate the gross impact (excluding transitional) is £157m from moving from -0.5% deferment rate to -1% and a further £60m impact from moving from 12% volatility estimate to 13%. The company already took a £470m impact from moving from +1% to -0.5% deferment rate as at 31st December 2017 (of which 70% had the benefit of a transitional).

FATDAZ @BE late to this issue re equity release mortgages but surely LYV or hair cuts on the total value of the property versus money released from it offers a better capital buffer for lenders ??
FATDAZ LTV should say
BE11:20am

You'll remember that the PRA had already pushed back implementation, taking much of the risk of a cash call off the table.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Just says it continues to review its balance sheet strength, though that is no longer a euphemism for a cash call.

BE11:21am

Panmure:

BE11:21am

The key positive is that the PRA has confirmed that transitional relief for technical provisions for pre-2016 business will be recognised for the remaining period to 31 Dec 2031. In addition, the Deferment rate will be 1% which compares to 0.5% that Just currently uses. The Volatility rate will initially be set at 13% which compares to the 12% currently uses. In our view the 1% and 13% rates are better than the 2%/18% some had feared. Lastly, the PRA has confirmed that it has no plans to apply the EVT approach to other assets.
New business pricing has already been adjusted in line with expected post CP13/18 capital requirements. Together with efficiency gains, Just has been able to increase its new business margin from 3.3% in 2015 to 10.2% in H1 2018.

wayneJ Morning all. If I may I would like to divert briefly today to highlight the following blog by the husband of Manjit Wostenholme who died just over a year ago (you may recall she was chair of Provident Financial) - https://blog.kloodle.com/why-i-have-decided-to-set-up-the-manjit-wolstenholme-foundation-58e0a1e3e09e
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Investment view – Whilst we think that the nightmare of CP13/18 is not over for shareholders, today’s announcement should be seen as a huge relief. We commented previously that it was almost impossible to value the business given the uncertainty but this is now lifting and we expect the share price to react accordingly. Based on our 2019F EPS estimates the shares are trading on an IFRS P/E multiple of only 4.0x, a 64% discount to 30 June 2018 Embedded Value of 230p/share and even more startling a 51% discount to IFRS NAV of 169p/share also at 30 June. We maintain our 168p/share targetprice. Buy.

BE11:23am

And RBC.

wayneJ Think it is a remarkable story and well worth reading.
BE11:23am

The share price has fallen 40% since the announcement from 135p and business results were 30% ahead of consensus (over the 9 months to 30 September). The business is flying, in our view, and the removal of uncertainty around the ERM consultation allows management to focus on key areas of growth, including, bulk annuities which we see as the best structural growth opportunity in Europe and a market where we believe £30bn is the new norm . This creates a compelling buying opportunity in our view.

wayneJ (The discussion re financial services reminded me I had meant to post that link a while back).
11:23 am
undefined
VV75 morning
FATDAZ @Wayne J thanks
BE11:25am

Anyone know why Centrica's down?

BE11:26am

I mean, it's my job to. But honestly I don't so we may as well crowdsource it.

11:25 am
Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 134.00, down 5.6 (-4.01%), High: 138.95, Low: 133.55, Volume: 7.29m
BE11:26am

The explanation given on the wires is the Sunday Tel.

BE11:26am

https://www.telegr...ose-wind-dividend/

11:27 am
BE11:27am

.... which is a rewrite of a UBS note, which came out on Wednesday.

BE11:27am

Centrica's latest trading update shows conditions are tougher than we thought: large customer losses have continued at British Gas (we now expect 7% attrition this year); production volumes are down in the asset businesses (guidance was cut for E&P); and commodity prices have been falling. All this puts pressure on the strategy, and we no longer see a skew of risks to the upside. Downgrade to Neutral, target price 135p.

BE11:28am

That one.

jaws BE I saw something from M stanley on Centrica
Patri morning
Lemmy Deutsche say sell CNA too
11:28 am
BE11:28am

.... and Centrica finished up on the day of publication there, so ......

VV75 anybody surprised by the Interserve news?
BE11:29am

..... in terms of the Morgan Stanley thing, it's kinda dull.

BE11:29am

Warm weather and low wind speeds could spell trouble for Q4 (particularly in France and Germany). Iberian weather looks normal though and UK wind speeds are up. Shares have been sensitive to weather beats/misses, so this is something to watch ahead of FY18 earnings.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

So, it's been warm.

BE11:29am

BE11:30am

European temperatures have been more than one degree warmer than the long term average so far in Q4 (Exhibit 1). This could mean heightened risk for stocks with large retail earnings in Germany (Innogy and E.ON), France (EDF and Engie), UK (Centrica) and to a lesser extent Italy given heating is mostly from gas (Enel). Spanish and Portuguese temperatures are in line with the long term average. Hence, this could be less of a risk for the likes of Iberdrola, Endesa and EDP.

Pharma So now share prices of £Bn companies are dependent on average wind speeds? What a strange world.
GBKrona Not surprised re@CNA - awful service means many more leaving as the word spreads. Lots of sharp commercial practices too IMHO.
11:30 am
BE11:31am

And the UK's not terribly notable on the heat vs wind ratio.

BE11:31am

France and Germany have the toughest mix of both softer wind speeds and warmer weather. Italy and the UK have been warmer but also windier, which can provide some help to those utilities with integrated business models. Iberia has been very much in line with long term averages.

Tom Dalgleish Any knife catchers feeling bold?
Pharma Re Finland temps - have a friend who was told with 24h notice that their daughter's trip to Lapland was cancelled due to lack of snow.
Noname @VV75 not particularly, that's Kier, Balfour and Interserve all publishing something in the last few weeks, I expect their peers to do the same soon
BE11:31am

MOST's underweight E.ON.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

DPL. That'll pass a few moments while we wait patiently for the inevitable. Peel Hunt sector review.

BE11:41am

Whether the Brexit deal passes through Parliament this week or not, we continue to see the longer-term prognosis for the UK housebuilding industry as favourable. This is due to the supply/demand imbalance, associated Government support and a much more liquid and benign land market. However, the short-term outlook for the UK housebuilders clearly remains volatile, mainly due to the economic uncertainty caused by the Brexit process. This has caused some consumers to defer house buying until there is more clarity on the outcome. While the fluid political backdrop could lead us to change our assumptions again shortly, for now our central case on growth has shifted lower and has led us to cut forecasts and target prices.

Dorian Gray https://twitter.com/owenjbennett/status/1072092782670594048
Pharma @Forrester - perhaps that's a solution for what question to put on the second referendum ballot - lethal injection or electric chair?
BE11:42am

I'll skip the stuff about Brexit being a point of uncertainty.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Revised assumptions – our previous models were assuming modest house price inflation for CY19-20 of c2% (with some regional and product variations). We have now cut this to zero. We have also trimmed our cost assumptions, but still expect to see 1-2% per annum in CY19-20. We have also taken 2-3% off volumes assumptions. Overall, we now forecast an aggregated revenue CAGR of 2% over the next two years (previously 4.3%) and an operating margin decline of 110bps (previously flat) to 18.4% between CY18 and CY20.

Forester @pharma or death by compulsory attendance at 15 years of tedious trade negotiations?
BE11:43am

Changes in forecasts – on average we have lowered our CY19 PBT estimates by 7% and CY20 by 10%. This leaves aggregate forecast FY20 PBT for the sector slightly lower (c1%) than FY18. The cash flow dynamics of the industry remain very healthy and the combination of profitability and a reduction in land spend sees our forecast sector net cash rise from £1.6bn in CY18 to £3.1bn over the next two years.

BE11:43am

(@Dorian: ta. I stupidly went to CityAM's website and then its Twitter feed, forgetting of course that these things are of secondary priority to the modern hack.)

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Changes in target prices and recommendations – on average we have reduced target prices by 17% to reflect both the lower forecasts and the lower target multiples we are now assuming. We are making four changes to recommendations – Barratt and Berkeley both to Add (from Buy), Crest to Reduce from Hold and Taylor Wimpey to Hold from Add.

BE11:44am

Let me have a scan to see if there's anything interesting in here.

We expect EU MedTech to perform in line with the EU market, despite relative valuation (2.1x) above the 10-year average of 1.7x. We also expect EU Services to perform in line with the EU market.

BE11:52am

We look at Valuation Dislocations within EU MedTech & Services, as 1 YR
forward P/E multiples remain elevated, and identify stocks we see as overdue a de-rating and offering attractive risk-reward profiles. Artificial Intelligence will gain momentum, and we set out a framework that points to Imaging and Siemens Healthineers as likely to benefit most. Potential Amazon Disruption within the MedTech sector could pick up pace in 2019 – we update our framework looking at which companies appear most exposed. We explore US-China tariff implications for companies in our sector. FX should be an earnings tailwind from a stronger US dollar, using spot rates, although our FX strategists expect the US dollar to depreciate against the euro to 1.31 by year-end 2019.

BE11:52am

That kind of thing. So .....

11:52 am
BE11:52am

1] Growth Recovery: Smith & Nephew should see a recovery in organic sales growth, led by new management. 2] Product Cycle: we think Straumann's midterm growth potential, driven by BLX and clear aligners, is underestimated by consensus. 3] Valuation Support: We believe Spire could benefit from an increase in NHS outsourcing. ConvaTec looks attractively valued, with organic sales growth recovering.

BE11:53am

You're thinking there must be more to it than that, right? And yes, there is.

Pharma @Waterloo, Merkel is no longer in charge in Germany, and Macron & the Italian double act have other things on their minds.
BE11:53am

We believe Spire Healthcare will see an improvement in its NHS
business, driven by new NHS England & Improvement guidance to reduce waiting lists and utilise the independent sector, prior and current investments in the Spire network beginning to deliver returns, and challenged peers creating opportunities to increase referrals market share.

Finlay Not sure what else the EU can do without kicking Ireland in the teeth
11:53 am
BE11:54am

As in .....

BE11:54am

We believe that pressures on the business could improve based on 1] the latest NHS Improvement letters, explicitly guiding CCGs and Trusts to use the independent sector; 2] the increased NHS funding, which should alleviate pressures to ration services; and 3] our discussions with industry experts lead us to believe that the new NHS 10-year plan is likely to reinforce patients' rights to elective care and put in place a renewed focus to reduce waiting lists. Spire also continues to hold strategic value based on its competitive position in the UK. The shares are trading at a ~35% discount to peers.

BE11:54am

NHS Improvement Censored

BE11:59am

French midcap aluminium? Righty ho. So the presser warns of nonconformance of the quality management system in the Alloys division.

BE12:00pm

What does this mean? Dunno. Alphavalue had a go at it.

IslandDweller 1st Ltd. The interesting thing will now be what is/are the question(s) for referendum2
Pharma @1st Lt. - based on chromosomal makeup, skin colour, annual income or land ownership perchance? Thought we had got past that sort of argument a while ago.
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Although the release is rather vague, we understand that quality issues have been spotted, with (at least so far) no impact on the safety of products delivered to clients, while further analysis is being conducted. As a reminder, the Alloys divisions represents c.25% of revenues, with products going into the aerospace, energy or defence sectors, where quality is obviously key. Further analysis is being conducted, with the group indicating that the potential impacts on the accounts are expected to be “material”, with no further assessment at this stage. The group asserts it will be in a position to assess the impact better when the FY results are released (i.e. on 20 February).

BE12:01pm

At this stage, we estimate that a material impact has to be at least in the €5-10m region, even if such an estimate is very questionable since it is only based on our feelings, which we will model. Of course too, the bigger the quality issues prove to be, the greater the reputation issue and the longer-term prospects for the division potentially be altered.

LegalEagle @islandDweller surely has to include a remain option ..
BE12:01pm

And a very short sentence from Merrill.

IslandDweller @LegalEagle. I would say so but rumour is that Mrs May doesn't want that
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Financial impact unknown but... ... expected "material" i.e. greater than EUR25 mn. But consider vs. EBITDA of c. EUR800-900 mn. Share price move overdone- Reiterate BUY.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @pharma - If you don't know what you are talking about you don't know what you are talking about. You need qualifications to do many jobs, voting should be no different. You need to protect many people from themselves!

Most of the weekend press following the FT Saturday story: https://www.ft.com...-af46-2022a0b02a6c

.... that we'll be getting The London Solution. Have to say, while checking this one out last week, was somewhat baffled to see the shares had a 2 handle.

BE12:07pm

Stifel:

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Following press reports over the weekend, Interserve acknowledges that it is engaged with lenders regarding the implementation of a de-leveraging plan. The group targets reducing net debt/EBITDA to c.1.5x, with the plan expected to involve the conversion of a substantial proportion of external borrowings to equity, likely resulting in material dilution to current shareholders. Current financing agreements would also be amended. With Interserve guiding to £625-650m year-end net debt in FY18E, target leverage of 1.5x implies the group reducing its net debt by c.£430-460m based on our FY18E forecasts. The group expects to announce the finalised plan in early 2019, with lenders "supportive" of the plan. The announcement and focus on a debt for equity swap is not a surprise given the group's highly elevated net debt and low market cap providing little room for manoeuvre. Increasing focus from public sector clients on balance sheet strength and pressure on supply chain payments as per recent comments from Kier (KIE.LN, Hold, 382p) and the Cabinet Office are likely to have increased the urgency of finding a de-leveraging solution. Kier also commented that lenders are reducing their exposure to the sector. Unlike Carillion, Interserve does not have a material pension deficit and doesn't use off balance sheet financing, making a de-leveraging plan more viable. Despite this, we view increased cost certainty from the exit from Energy from Waste as a key prerequisite for implementing any plan
